def: {bc} a person or way of behaving that is seen as a model that should be followed
{bc} someone or something that is mentioned to help explain what you are saying or to show that a general statement is true
{bc} something or someone chosen from a group in order to show what the whole group is like

dt: {bc}a person or way of behaving that is seen as a model that should be followed

dt.t: He was inspired by the {it}example{/it} of his older brother. [=he wanted to do what his older brother did]
You should try to follow her {it}example{/it}. [=try to do as she does]
Let that be an {it}example{/it} to you! [=let that show you what you should or should not do]
He set a good/bad {it}example{/it} for the rest of us.
It's up to you to {phrase}set an example{/phrase}. [=to behave in a way that shows other people how to behave]
She chooses to {phrase}lead by example{/phrase}. [=to lead by behaving in a way that shows others how to behave]

dt: {bc}someone or something that is mentioned to help explain what you are saying or to show that a general statement is true

dt.t: She gave/offered several {it}examples{/it} to show that the program is effective.

dt: {bc}something or someone chosen from a group in order to show what the whole group is like

dt.t: We've chosen three {it}examples{/it} of contemporary architecture for closer study.
a classic {it}example{/it} of a Persian rug
a fine/prime {it}example{/it} of the artist's work

dt: {bc}a phrase or sentence that shows how a word is used

dt.t: The dictionary includes thousands of {it}examples{/it}.

dt: {bc}something (such as a problem that a student has to solve) that is used to teach how a rule or process works

dt.t: arithmetic {it}examples{/it}

dt: used when you are mentioning a specific person or thing that helps to explain what you are saying or to show that a general statement is true

dt.t: Things are getting better. Last year, {it}for example{/it} [={it}for instance{/it}], the company achieved record sales in Europe.
It was obvious that her memory was failing. {it}For example{/it}, she would often forget where she put her car keys.
A lot of my friends were there—John and Linda, {it}for example{/it}.

dt: If you {it}make an example of{/it} a person who has done something wrong, you punish that person as a way of warning other people not to do the same thing.

dt.t: Although it was only his first offense, the judge decided to {it}make an example of him{/it} and sentence him to prison.

shortdef: a person or way of behaving that is seen as a model that should be followed
someone or something that is mentioned to help explain what you are saying or to show that a general statement is true
something or someone chosen from a group in order to show what the whole group is like

follow the line of least resistance

def: {bc} to go or come after or behind (someone or something)
{bc} to go after or behind (someone) secretly and watch to find out what happens
{bc} to come after (something) in time or place or as part of a series

dt: {bc}to go or come after or behind (someone or something)

dt.t: She {it}followed{/it} us into the kitchen.
The dog {it}followed{/it} the children home.
The exit is right this way. Just {it}follow{/it} me.
The children went home and the dog {it}followed{/it} behind.
If one sheep goes through the gate, the rest will {it}follow{/it}.

dt: {bc}to go after or behind (someone) secretly and watch to find out what happens

dt.t: He hired a private detective to {it}follow{/it} his wife everywhere. [=to secretly find out where she went and what she did]
{it}follow{/it} a suspect
I think that someone is {it}following{/it} us. = I think we're being {it}followed{/it}.

dt: {bc}to come after (something) in time or place or as part of a series

dt.t: Spring {it}follows{/it} winter. = Winter {it}is followed{/it} by spring.
The number 15 {it}follows{/it} 14.
Her accident was {it}followed{/it} by a long period of recovery.
First came the student speeches, and the presentation of awards {it}followed{/it}.
({it}formal){/it} The war ended. {phrase}There followed{/phrase} [={it}then came{/it}; then there was] a long period of rebuilding.

dt: {bc}to have or do something after (something else)

dt.t: I {it}followed{/it} my dinner {it}with{/it} a liqueur. [=I had a liqueur after dinner]
The actor {it}followed{/it} his success as Othello {it}with{/it} a triumph as Macbeth.

dt: {bc}to happen after and as a result of (something)

dt.t: Rioting {it}followed{/it} the unjust verdict.
If you work hard, success will/must surely {it}follow{/it}.

dt: {bc}to be true or seem to be true because of something

dt.t: From the evidence given, several conclusions {it}follow{/it}. = Several conclusions {it}follow{/it} from the evidence given. [=we can make several conclusions based on the evidence given]
From the evidence given, it {it}follows that{/it} the accused is guilty.
Just because he's done some bad things, does/must it {it}follow that{/it} he's a bad person? [=does it mean that he is a bad person?]
You should {it}follow{/it} [={it}obey{/it}] your conscience.
{it}follow{/it} your instincts
{it}follow{/it} my advice
She must learn to {it}follow{/it} instructions.

She {it}followed{/it} her father (by going) into medicine. = She {it}followed{/it} her father by becoming a doctor.

dt: {bc}to move forward on (a road, a path, etc.)

dt.t: {it}Follow{/it} that path, and you will come to a log cabin.
You should {it}follow{/it} the main highway until you see signs for the stadium.
His friends all went to college, but he chose to {it}follow{/it} a different path. [=to do something different]
Do recessions {it}follow{/it} a predictable cycle/pattern?

dt: {bc}to be on or next to (something) for a distance

dt.t: The path {it}follows{/it} the river pretty closely.
The road {it}follows{/it} the curve of the hill.

dt: {bc}to keep your eyes or attention on (something)

dt.t: {it}Follow{/it} the bouncing ball.

dt: {bc}to give close attention to what happens in (something)

dt.t: He {it}followed{/it} her career with interest.
{it}follow{/it} football
The book {it}follows{/it} his political career from its humble beginnings to his election as president.
He {it}follows{/it} Manchester United.

dt: {bc}to understand the sense or logic of (something or someone)

dt.t: I found it hard to {it}follow{/it} the twists and turns of the movie's complicated plot.
I'm sorry—I don't {it}follow{/it} your argument/reasoning. = I'm sorry—I don't {it}follow{/it} you. [=I don't understand you]
I'm sorry—I don't {it}follow{/it}. [=I don't understand]

dt: {bc}someone or something that has been so successful that it is very difficult for the person or thing coming next to be as good

dt.t: Yesterday's thrilling victory will be {it}a tough act to follow{/it}.

dt: used to introduce a list, a statement, instructions, etc.

dt.t: The names of the finalists are {it}as follows{/it}: Mary, James, and George.
Proceed {it}as follows{/it}: go straight ahead to Martin Street and then turn left.
The little boy {it}followed{/it} his mother {it}around{/it} all day.

dt: {bc}to play a card of the same suit (such as hearts or spades) as the card that was played just before

dt.t: Jane played a spade, and Roger {it}followed suit{/it}.

dt: {bc}to do the same thing that someone else has just done

dt.t: His brother went to medical school, and he {it}followed suit{/it}.
After one airline lowers their fares, the other airlines usually {it}follow suit{/it}.

dros.drp: follow the path/line of least resistance

dt: {bc}to complete an activity or process that has been started

dt.t: He always starts the school year off studying and working hard, but he doesn't {it}follow through{/it}. [=he doesn't continue to study and work hard]
He doesn't {it}follow{/it} his good intentions {it}through{/it}. [=although he makes plans to do things, he doesn't actually do them]
He doesn't {it}follow through on{/it} his good intentions.
We feared they would {it}follow through on/with{/it} their threat. [=we feared that they would do what they threatened to do]

dt: {bc}to keep your arms, legs, etc., moving after you hit or kick a ball {bc}to complete a stroke or swing

dt.t: You should {it}follow through{/it} on your backhand.
Don't forget to {it}follow through{/it} when you putt.

dt: {bc}to follow (something) with something similar, related, or additional

dt.t: He {it}followed up{/it} his early findings {it}with{/it} another study.
After you submit your job application, you should {it}follow{/it} it {it}up by{/it} making a phone call.
Her first book was a big success, and she {it}followed up with{/it} another best seller.

dt: {bc}to try to get more information about (something)

dt.t: The police {it}followed up (on){/it} the leads.
The references in the book were too vague to {it}follow up{/it}.

dt: {bc}to do something in response to (something) {bc}to take appropriate action about (something)

dt.t: Police {it}followed up{/it} the complaints with several arrests.
He complained several times, but the police never {it}followed up{/it}.
He says that the police failed to {it}follow up on{/it} his complaints.

dt: {bc}to go in a straight or obvious course

dt.t: Just {it}follow your nose{/it} until you get there; you can't miss it.

dt: {bc}to proceed without a definite plan {bc}to do what seems right or best without careful planning

dt.t: You don't need my advice—just {it}follow your nose{/it}.

dt: {bc}to go toward the place where a smell is coming from

dt.t: I {it}followed my nose{/it} to the kitchen, where dinner was cooking.

shortdef: to go or come after or behind (someone or something)
to go after or behind (someone) secretly and watch to find out what happens
to come after (something) in time or place or as part of a series

lead someone down/up the garden path

def: {bc} to guide someone to a place especially by going in front
{bc} to go or be at the front part of (something)
{bc} to lie or go in a specified direction

dt: {bc}to guide someone to a place especially by going in front

dt.t: You {it}lead{/it} and we'll follow right behind you.
He {it}led{/it} [={it}took{/it}] me into a room in the back of the house.
You {it}lead{/it} us and we'll follow right behind you.
The teacher {it}led{/it} the child by the hand {it}to{/it} his seat. = The teacher took the child's hand and {it}led{/it} him {it}to{/it} his seat.
Our hostess {it}led{/it} us {it}to{/it} the dinner table.
The passengers {it}were led{/it} onto/aboard the ship by the steward.
The prisoner {it}was{/it} {phrase}led off{/phrase} to jail [=was taken to jail] in handcuffs.
I gradually {it}led{/it} the interview around/back to the subject of his failed marriage.
He says that he will follow the evidence wherever it {it}leads{/it} (him).
This {it}leads{/it} me to my next point, which is that the building needs a new roof.
The painting's composition {phrase}leads the/your eye{/phrase} to the figures in the foreground. [=causes you to look at the figures in the foreground]

dt: {bc}to go or be at the front part of (something)

dt.t: The veterans will {it}lead{/it} a parade down Main Street.
{it}lead{/it} a march

dt: {bc}to lie or go in a specified direction

dt.t: The path {it}leads{/it} uphill.
This road doesn't {it}lead{/it} to the village as we thought it did.
a set of stairs that {it}leads{/it} down to the basement
There was a path {it}leading{/it} (off) from the meadow into the woods.
She realized that their relationship would never {it}lead{/it} to marriage.
The investigation into the murder was {phrase}leading nowhere{/phrase}. [=the investigation was not solving the crime]

dt: {bc}to guide the actions of a person or group {bc}to be in charge of a person, group, activity, etc.

dt.t: We need to elect someone who can {it}lead{/it}.
bosses who {phrase}lead by example{/phrase} [=who show employees how they should act by acting that way themselves]
She {it}leads{/it} her employees by setting a good example for them.
She {it}led{/it} a successful boycott of the store.
{it}lead{/it} an expedition
A visiting professor will be {it}leading{/it} the seminar.
{it}lead{/it} [={it}direct{/it}] an orchestra
She {it}led{/it} the children in a song. [=she sang a song and the children sang with her]

dt: {bc}to cause (a person, group, etc.) to do something or to follow some course of action

dt.t: Her interest in art {it}led{/it} her into the field of art history.
His volunteer work in the hospital {it}led{/it} him {it}to{/it} a career in nursing. = His volunteer work in the hospital {it}led{/it} [={it}inspired{/it}] him {it}to become{/it} a nurse.
Her experience with cancer {it}led{/it} her {it}to consider{/it} writing a book on the subject.
The evidence {it}leads{/it} me {it}to believe{/it} [=makes me believe] that this disease is curable.
We've been {it}led to believe{/it} that the labels on food items disclose all ingredients, but it's becoming clear that this is not the case.
I had been {it}led to expect{/it} that someone would meet me at the airport, but no one came.
He {it}led me to understand{/it} [=he told me or caused me to think] that the deadline was January 7.

dt: {bc}to be first, best, or ahead in a race or competition

dt.t: the team that is currently {it}leading{/it} in the pennant race
At the end of the fourth inning, the Red Sox {it}led{/it} by two runs.
{it}lead{/it} a race
They {it}led{/it} their opponents by 20 points at the end of the third quarter.
the team that is {it}leading{/it} the league [=the team that is in first place]
a batter who {it}leads{/it} the league in home runs [=who has hit more home runs than any other batter]
a runner who is {phrase}leading the pack/field{/phrase} [=a runner who is ahead of the group of other runners]
Their company {phrase}leads the world{/phrase} [=is the most successful company in the world] in developing new technology to assist people with disabilities.

dt: {bc}to go through (life) in a certain way {bc}to have (a specified kind of life)

dt.t: They chose to {it}lead{/it} [={it}live{/it}] a quiet life.
He {it}leads{/it} a peaceful existence.
It turned out that he had been {phrase}leading a double life{/phrase}. [=deceiving people about his life, not telling the whole truth about his life]
He has always {phrase}led a charmed life{/phrase}. [=he has always been lucky]
She needs to {phrase}lead her own life{/phrase}. [=she needs to make her own decisions about her life]

dt.t: {it}lead{/it} trumps
{it}led{/it} a spade

dt.t: I don't know this dance, so I'd prefer it if you {it}lead{/it}.

dt: {bc}to ask (a witness) a question in a way that suggests what the answer should be {bc}to ask (a witness) a leading question

dt.t: The judge ruled that the lawyer was {it}leading{/it} the witness.

dt: {bc}to start something (such as an activity or performance) in a specified way

dt.t: She {it}led off{/it} [={it}started, kicked off{/it}] the presentation with a brief overview of the project.

dt.t: He {it}led off{/it} with a walk. [=he was the first batter in his team's half of the inning and he was walked]

dt: {bc}to cause (someone) to wrongly continue believing or doing something

dt.t: She was devastated when she found out that he didn't really love her, and had only been {it}leading{/it} her {it}on{/it}. [=he had been leading her to believe that he loved her]

dt: {bc}to cause a series of troubles or worries for (someone)

dt.t: He {it}led me a merry chase{/it} before I finally got him to agree to a meeting.

dt: {bc}to be the first person to go somewhere

dt.t: You {it}lead the way{/it}, and we'll follow.

His volunteer work in the hospital {it}led to{/it} a career in nursing. = His volunteer work in the hospital {it}led to{/it} him becoming a nurse.

dt: {bc}to occur in the time that comes before (something)

dt.t: Many voters were still undecided in the days {it}leading up to{/it} [={it}approaching{/it}] the election.

dt: {bc}to come before and help to cause (something)

I had no idea what he was {it}leading up to{/it} when he started talking about his father.

dt: {bc}to begin something (such as a story or speech) with (something specified)

dt.t: The newspaper story {it}led{/it} [={it}opened, began{/it}] {it}with{/it} a long report on the funeral.

dt.t: The champion {it}led with{/it} a left to the body, followed up quickly with a right to the jaw.

to go or be at the front part of (something)

dt: {bc}most likely or very likely to be chosen for something, to experience something, etc.

def: {bc} to put (something) in a place or position
{bc} to put (something) into the surface of something
{bc} to attach (something, such as a jewel) to a piece of jewelry or other decoration

lbs: always followed by an adverb or preposition

dt: {bc}to put (something) in a place or position

dt: {bc}to put (something) into the surface of something

dt.t: They {it}set{/it} the bricks along the walkway.
The posts {it}are set{/it} firmly in the ground.
The tiles {it}are set{/it} into the wall.

dt: {bc}to attach (something, such as a jewel) to a piece of jewelry or other decoration

dt.t: The jeweler can {it}set{/it} the stone several different ways.

a diamond {it}set{/it} in a simple gold band

lbs: always followed by an adverb or preposition
dt: {bc}to cause the action of (a film, story, etc.) to happen in a certain place or during a certain time

a novel {it}set{/it} during World War II
The story {phrase}is set against{/phrase} (the backdrop of) the Second World War. [=the story takes place during the Second World War]

dt: {bc}to make (something) ready to be used {bc}to put (something) in a position to be used

dt.t: He turned off the car and {it}set{/it} the parking brake.

dt: {bc}to put plates, forks, spoons, knives, etc., on a table before serving a meal

dt: {bc}to cause (a clock) to show a particular time

dt: {bc}to cause the controls of (a clock or other device) to be in a particular position

dt.t: The alarm was {it}set{/it} for 7:00 a.m. = The alarm was {it}set{/it} to go off at 7:00 a.m.

{it}Set{/it} the oven to 350 degrees.

He has {phrase}set his sights on{/phrase} becoming [=he has decided to try to become] the next president.
We don't have enough time to do everything. We have to {phrase}set priorities{/phrase}. [=to decide which things are most important to do]

dt: {bc}to give (a particular price or value) to something

dt.t: An antiques appraiser {it}set{/it} the value of the chair at $500.
If you {it}set{/it} your prices too high, no one will buy your products.
Her bail was {it}set{/it} at $10,000. = The judge {it}set{/it} (her) bail at $10,000. [=the judge decided that she will have to pay $10,000 or stay in jail until her trial]

dt: {bc}to give (a high value or importance) to something

dt.t: They {it}set{/it} a high value on their privacy. [=they value their privacy very highly]

dt: {bc}to cause (something) to be accepted as an example, rule, etc. {bc}to establish (a standard, trend, etc.) for others to follow or try to copy

dt.t: They are improving the safety of their vehicles and {it}setting{/it} a higher standard for other companies (to follow).
His style of directing has {it}set{/it} a new trend in moviemaking. [=other directors are copying his way of making movies]
His behavior {phrase}sets a good/bad example{/phrase} for the rest of the children.

dt: {bc}to establish (a record) as the performance or achievement that is the best of its kind

dt.t: She {it}set{/it} a record for the most sales in the company's history. [=she made more sales for the company than anyone else ever had]

dt: {bc}to cause (someone or something) to be in a specified condition

dt.t: The slaves were {it}set{/it} free.
He made a raft and {it}set{/it} it afloat in the river.

They {phrase}set{/phrase} the house {phrase}on fire{/phrase}. = They {phrase}set fire to{/phrase} the house. = (more formally) They {it}set{/it} the house afire/aflame/ablaze. [=they caused the house to begin burning]

dt: {bc}to cause (someone or something) to start doing something

dt.t: We have no idea what {it}set{/it} [={it}got{/it}] her crying.

dt: {bc}to give (someone) a particular job {bc}to require someone to do (a task)

{it}setting{/it} homework for the children

dt: {bc}to move down in the sky and go below the horizon
